title: Who Could Possibly Challenge Aurelion Sol?
body:
His lore is just so insanely OP that in fact, it just seems like it's an impossibility that anybody could ever challenge him, period.

Lore power goes from:
{{champion:55}} {{champion:86}} I use weapons skillfully to
{{champion:92}} {{champion:157}} I use weapons skillfully plus magic to
{{champion:103}} {{champion:1}} {{champion:101}} we don't use weapons but we use magic- to
{{champion:31}} {{champion:3}} We are colossal beings that should be respected as devastating creatures- to
{{champion:136}} Yeah, well. I create universes. And make stars orbit around me, because that's just how massive I really am. Wanna 1v1 me mid?

I can't help but feel like this god-dragon is just so OP that it is impossible to relate him to literally anything at all - he is just THAT massively different compared to everybody. It would've been better if he was like {{champion:34}} who at least represents a spirit that is capable of being challenged by other people like {{champion:127}} 

Thoughts?

Serious question: Why is Bard considered to be so powerful? He's mentioned several times in this thread, and whenever there is a thread about "power levels" Bard always comes out close to the top.
Why?
We know nothing about Bard. Why are people so sure he is god-tier powerful?

Because bard is the guy who makes sure that the universe doesn't collapse.
Meaning its Bards job to stop catastrophes that threaten whole worlds or even the very fabric of reality.

And since he has to deal with these massive threats,he is likely quite powerful.

Though there are probably a lot of people who overhype him a bit too much(some even claiming that bard is a god or that he could easily annihilate everything,which is rather unlikely).

It is said that with great power comes great responsibility. But great responsibility does not necessarily entail great power.

Bard is obviously magical. He is obviously cosmic. But I see no reason to consider him to be that much more powerful than any of Lague's mages, Ascended, Targonians, etc...

Something to think about: Bard uses a tool of some kind to work his magic. It looks like a saxophone. So is Bard's power really his own, or does it originate in the tool? What would happen if someone took that saxophone away from him?

Overall the way I understand it,it is more likely that bard is simply really really wise.
It was said that he often does some things that appear to be trivial at first,but then have a great effect later on.

In this case he likely wouldn't have much raw power,but the sole fact that he can predict events unfolding like this is indeed a huge power.
As I know, his harmonica/flute/saxophone (whatever you say) is just a tool to help for channeling his magic easier. I'm pretty sure he is not useless without it.
I think Riot said the tool is what he uses to travel between worlds/dimensions.

A few comments from Rioters have implied that Bard's real power is knowledge. Claiming if Bard saves you, it's not because you're important. It's because 11 generations down your offspring will be important. Which means he has pretty insane abilities to know the future. 

Similarly, Sol mentions that Bard exists in multiple dimensions and that jumping between them confuses the normal people. 

This all leads to Bard being kind of like The Doctor from Doctor Who if you watched the show. In it, The Doctor is a bit stronger, and smarter than those around him, has technology that is super advanced and allows him to jump through time. But in terms of real physical power The Doctor facing off against any of his usual main villains and he'd be squashed like a bug. Similarly a bullet could kill him. 

But the Doctor nearly always wins because he is playing by different rules to his enemies. He does not get into situations where it's a slug out brawl, unless the deck is so ridiculously stacked in his favor it's not even a contest anymore. 

That's Bard. If you ever threw him and Sol in a cage match, Sol would probably blow him up. But there is next to no chance for Bard to ever get caught in that situation. While Sol, for all his power, got played a fool by a piece of bling.
An excellent comparison. I like the idea of Bard being a master manipulator on a cosmic scale.

Actually Pantheon IS the Targonian from Aurelion Lore, but his body isnt. They are like spirits that take over the body of a human... is weird.
I was talking about the champions, if I was referring to the Targonian I would say "the Pantheon" as they are called in the lore.

Pantheon the champion IS THE PANTHEON aka the Aspect of War/ Targonian spirit of War. Unlike other aspects the Aspect of War completely replaces the persona of their vessel with their own/ a new one. 
Pantheon is the closest to being the actual Targonian than any other aspect we know of, outside of gameplay issues the fact that he doesn't convey this 'god of war' theme is a major factor as to why he is slated for a rework.

He is _almost_ the Pantheon itself.  It is still Atreus's body and that makes a difference.  I doubt that the Pantheon has zero powers beyond being perfect or nigh perfect at fighting in mundane ways.

Assuming that the Aspect does have additional powers just because they haven't been shown as of yet doesn't mean he can't use them.
Even if they can't use their powers while in Atreus' body that doesn't make them any less of the Aspect of war, what is important is the inhabitancy of Atreus' body with their psyche not the powers.  It makes sense as a trade off as well, reduced powers for full control over the vessel.

Here is a quote from Pantheon's lore:  "They are not immortal, limited by the human flesh they inhabit, and can be killed, though it takes great effort to do so."  Another thing of note from Pantheon's lore is that the Pantheon is the Aspect of the Warrior, not War (just a nomenclature thing, I doubt it makes a huge difference).

Also worth mentioning from Aurelion's lore is that Pantheon is not the entirety of the Pantheon, he is merely one avatar of many scattered across the cosmos.

My opinion is that the powers do matter.  Since Pantheon is not the entirety of the Pantheon, I do not consider him as the Pantheon but merely some lesser amount of it.  I also am not 100% convinced that Atreus is completely gone, but that is a discussion that could be long and arduous.

Offensive language isn't tolerated around these parts. Respect your god, lord and savior, Aurelion Sol.
Xerath and Syndra are both potentially omnipotent, for one.

Syndra is powerful,but definetly not omnipotent.
Xerath is in a similar boat,at least as long as he is bound by that sarcophagus

I annoys me a lot when people say Syndra is, or can become, omnipotent.
Whatever her powers may be, she has a human mind. If she became omnipotent she would be rendered brain-dead in milliseconds.

Omnipotent doesnt necessarily have to include omniscience.  People argue Syndra and Xerath have the potential to become omnipotent because they are really the only two mages that seem to hint at having unlimited potential canonically in lore.  Additionally we can't just limit a mages mind to what we know about humans, for all we know they could have special adaptations to suit.

But yh haha, it's doubtful either are actually omnipotent as no entity so far in league actually is omnipotent, just extremely powerful.  It is generally thought however that Syndra will naturally achieve what Xerath had to Ascend to achieve

Honestly we don't know how powerful syndra is compared to Xerath,so its a bit too early to say that she could achieve the same as Xerath.

We've barely seen the 2 in action within the lore,so its hard to compare them.
The important thing is that both are a lot more powerful than most other champions(I mean Xerath for example defeated Nasus rather easily and that despite the fact that he is basically bound to a power limiter),but not omnipotent

Moments after commenting, I realised I'd confused omnipotence and omniscience in my mind. Silly Epicurus.

Syndra is definitely powerful, but I don't buy that she might become infinitely powerful. Her lore is too old to have a serious discussion about anyway. Having unlimited power is just silly, and detracts from the story, in my humble opinion.

Xerath, I make an exception for, as he is no longer a flesh and blood being. And because his lore is up to date. One can only imagine what he would be like unchained.

I said POTENTIALLY.

Because Riot has said previously that both characters are theoretically able to become omnipotent.

Illaoi, her God is so much more powerful than Aurelion that it isn't even a fight, though whether it would help is another matter.  

To mention a couple things:  Aurelion Sol didn't create galaxies.  In fact he didn't make MOST of the stars, only some of them.  Now he is powerful sure, but he is lacking in a number of areas and most certainly isn't anywhere near the top of the food chain.

Bard might be comparable.  Bard is able to cross multiple universes and has possibly existed longer than Aurelion Sol.  Sol on the other hand is bound to this Universe.  

Nagakabouros also completely outclasses him.  Nagaka is a true god, while Aurelion Sol is just a creature.  A powerful one to be sure, and very very old, but still capable of dying and possessing nothing resembling omnipotence or the like.  If Nagaka is the sky and we are just small eddies in the wind then Aurelion Sol would be nothing more than a light breeze.

There are a number of Rioter comments about stuff like this but I can't dig them up.

I don't think Illoai could, while she certainly had ties with nagakabouros, it's in the way that a priest has ties with their god. While she is empowered by her god, she doesn't understand it, let alone how to channel her to the effectiveness that would be required to beat Sol. So apart from nagakaburos directly intervening and defeating Sol that way (which it easily could), Illoai would most likely win.
Nocturne might be able to contest with him. Nocturne's real form is formless and is the embodiment of fear and nightmares in all beings.

I'd say Bard for sure, in terms of raw power. Bard's power isn't as...flashy or destructive though. Aurelion Sol would win in a race of destruction, but I doubt he could actually *defeat* Bard so much as stalemate him. Kindred is another contender, although we don't know if Kindred is only a minor avatar confined to Runeterra or part of a greater entity that handles death on a cosmic scale.

Nagakabouros would, I suspect, wipe the floor with Aurelion Sol and *maybe* Bard as well.

Unfortunately, the information concerning bards power is very mysterious and 'not very present.' Not that I doubt he could contest or beat Sol, but I would need to really know what the guy can do other than transcend reality.
